Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A bride-to-be and her entourage arrive early, visibly anxious about the tight wedding schedule.
Story: I was sweeping up stray hair from the salon floor when my phone buzzed. It was a text from my younger brother: “Can you call me? I really need you.” My heart squeezed. He never asked for help unless it was serious. But just as I was about to step outside, the front door chimed. The bride-to-be and her bridesmaids bustled in, faces tense, glancing at their watches. My manager shot me a look—this was the biggest booking of the month, and I was expected to greet them, offer tea, and set everyone at ease. I could see the bride’s hands trembling, her mother’s anxious eyes darting around the salon. I knew I was supposed to be the calm, welcoming professional, but my mind was with my brother, wondering what he needed, if he was okay. The weight of both worlds pressed on me—my family needing my support, my clients needing my attention. I stood frozen, phone in hand, torn between the sister my brother counted on and the hairdresser my clients expected.
